OpenAI's Naming Scheme Makes No Sense

April 17, 2025 1 min read

OpenAI just dropped the o3 family today, and I‚Äôm starting to think they‚Äôre trolling us. We have o3, o3-mini, and o3-pro. But wait‚Äîthere‚Äôs no o2 because of some British telecom trademark. So we‚Äôre skipping numbers now?

Here‚Äôs where it gets ridiculous: o3-mini launched in January, three months before o3 itself. That‚Äôs like releasing the iPhone mini before announcing the iPhone exists.

I‚Äôve been trying to keep track of their lineup: GPT-4, GPT-4o, o1-preview, o3-mini, o3, o3-pro. What does any of this mean? The ‚Äúo‚Äù supposedly stands for reasoning optimization, but good luck explaining to a client why they need o3-pro instead of GPT-4o for their use case.

The Developer Nightmare

Developers are stuck choosing between gpt-4o, o1-preview, and now three flavors of o3 in their API calls. Each has different pricing and capabilities, but the names tell you absolutely nothing about what you‚Äôre getting.

Meanwhile, Apple just goes iPhone 14, iPhone 15, iPhone 16. Revolutionary concept: numbers that go up.

The worst part? This actually matters when you‚Äôre building applications. Is o3-mini better than o1? How does o3 compare to GPT-4o? Nobody knows without diving into technical documentation that probably doesn‚Äôt exist yet.

From Simple to Chaos

OpenAI went from the beautifully simple GPT-3, GPT-4 progression to whatever fever dream this has become. At this point, I‚Äôm expecting them to release GPT-œÄ next, followed by GPT-‚àö2-ultra-mini-pro.

Maybe hire someone who passed elementary math before naming your next model?

Update (August 2025): Plot twist‚ÄîGPT-5 is actually called GPT-5. Sometimes the universe makes sense after all.
